questions.text:
A patient presents with dull aching pain in both legs. He gives a history of prolonged standing and tortuous veins in the legs. Which of the below mentioned tests are done for saphenofemoral incompetence?
1. Vegan
2. Morrissey
3. Modified pethes
4. Brodie trendelenberg
questions.solution:
Tests for SF junction incompetence are

  1. Morrisey cough impulse test
  2. Tredelenberg test 1
  3. Multiple trorniquet test

MORRISEY'S COUGH IMPULSE

  • Limb is elevated to empty the veins and the limb is then put to bed and the patient is asked to cough forcibly.
  • An expansile impulse is felt at the saphenofemoral junction in cases of saphenofemoral incompetence.
  • Bruit may be heard on auscultation at that spot.

FEGAN'S TEST

  • After marking the blowouts make the patient lie down to empty the veins.
  • Palate for the gaps or pits in the deep fascia, through which perforator enters.

MODIFIED PERTHE'S TEST

  • To find deep vein thrombosis
  • Important preliminary to do this test is that there should not be any perforator incompetence to do this test.
  • Steps
    1. Tourniquet is applied below the saphenofemoral junction (no need to milk the veins before applying tourniquet).
    2. Ask the patient to walk with a tourniquet.
  • Observation
    1. Shrinking of varicose veins: Indicates that there is normal deep veins and perforators (if there is perforator incompetence there will not be shrinking of veins)
    2. More prominence of varicose veins associated with severe crampy pain: Indicates there is deep vein thrombosis.

BRODIE - TRENDELENBURG TEST

  • Test - 1: For sapheno - femoral incompetence
  • Test - 2: For perforator incompetence
  • PROCEDURE
    • Step 1: Patient in recumbent position, legs raised to empty the veins, may be hastened by milking the veins.
    • Step 2: Tourniquet is applied below the saphenofemoral junction (thumb may be used to occlude the SF junction).
  • Test 1:
    • Pressure released at the SF junction.
    • Varices fill very quickly from above
  • Test 1 is positive, e. saphenofemoral incompetence is present.
  • Test  2: Do not release the pressure for one minute. Gradual filling of veins occurs in the lower limb.
  • Test  2 is positive: (i.e.) perforator incompetence is present.

questions.text: In a patient presenting with rectal prolapse, which of the following procedures is not done via perineal approach?
questions.solution:
Perineal approach

Useful in very old age who cannot withstand abdominal operation

Recurrence is more (>20%)

  • Delorme's mucosectomy operation of removal of rectal mucosa and placating the muscle layer
  • Thiersch anal encirclement operation
  • Altemeier's perineal recto sigmoidectomy procedure with Coloanal anastomosis Resection procedure

Abdominal approach

  • Procedure of choice\in young age
  • Least recurrence
    • Ripstein's anterior rectopexy
    • Well's posterior rectopexy
    • Resection rectopexy (Frykman and Goldberg) for redundant sigmoid colon
    • Ventral rectopexy-biological mesh used

KEYTAKEAWAYS:

questions.text: A patient presents with h\o dysentery and fever for the past 6 weeks. Along with that there is associated upper abdominal pain. USG show abscess with irregular margins in the liver. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The typical patient with an amoebic liver abscess is a young adult male with a history of insidious onset of non-specifc symptoms (in 2\3rd patients), such as abdominal pain, anorexia, fever, night sweats, malaise, cough and weight loss.

These symptoms gradually progress to more specifc symptoms of pain in the right upper abdomen and right shoulder tip, hiccoughs and a non-productive cough.

A past history of bloody diarrhoea (in 1/3rd patients only) or travel to an endemic area raises the index of suspicion.

Amoebiasis: pathology

  • histolytica is the most common pathogenic amoeba in humans
  • The vast majority of carriers are asymptomatic
  • Insanitary conditions and poor personal hygiene encourage transmission of the infection
  • In the small intestine, the parasite hatches into trophozoites, which invade the submucosa to produce fask-shaped ulcers in the colon
  • In the portal circulation, the parasite causes liquefactive necrosis in the liver, producing an abscess, the commonest extraintestinal manifestation
  • The majority of abscesses occur in the right lobe of the liver
  • A mass in the course of the large bowel may indicate an amoeboma

Option c) Pyogenic liver abscess appears as peripherally enhancing, centrally hypoattenuating lesions. Seen in immunocompromised patients.

Option d) hydatid cyst - Hydatid disease is caused by Echinococcus granulosus, commonly called the dog tapeworm. H\o dog handling will be present. The dog is the defnitive host and is the commonest source of infection transmitted to the intermediate hosts - humans, sheep and cattle.

choices.text: Post operative radiation is not compulsory

questions.text: Regarding breast conservation surgery, which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
• Breast conservation surgery (BCS) is aimed at removing the tumour along with a 1-cm margin of normal breast tissue (frozen section can be done).
  • Patients with involved margins should have a revision of margins called a 'cavity shave'.
  • All patients with BCS receive radiotherapy. BCS together with radiotherapy is called breast conservation therapy (BCT): BCS + RT = BCT.
  • BCS is, however, best avoided in patients with a
    1. multicentric tumour
    2. diffuse microcalcifcations on a mammogram
    3. a large tumour-to-breast ratio
    4. two times positive surgical margins after re-excision
    5. a history of previous breast or chest wall radiation
    6. systemic lupus erythematosus or other collagen vascular disease (these patients have a high risk of a radiation reaction), or ankylosing spondylitis;
    7. it is also best avoided in those with severe orthopnoea (as the patient cannot lie on the radiation table).
  • Axillary node dissection is done if palpable nodes are present, if the nodes are not palpable SENTINEL LYMPH NODE BIOPSY (SNB) is done, if SNB is +ve then axillary node dissection done, if SNB -ve then axillary node dissection is not done.

questions.text: What variant of gallbladder is shown in the USG image below?
questions.solution:
The Phrygian cap

The Phrygian cap (fundus of gallbladder folded) is present in 5% of gallbladders and may be mistaken for pathological deformity.

Option b) Gallbladder polyp - On ultrasound a gallbladder polyp is seen as an elevation of the gallbladder wall that protrudes into the lumen. It should not be mobile or demonstrate posterior acoustic shadowing (which would suggest it is more likely a calculus). It may be sessile or pedunculated.

Option d) Mercedes-Benz sign - gallstones signs in USG

questions.text: A 73-year-old male presents to the OPD with chronic bleeding per rectum. Which of the following tests is used for confirmation?
questions.solution:
Dd's for chronic bleeding per rectum:

  1. Haemorrhoids
  2. Fissure
  3. Malignancy
  4. Ulcerative colitis
  5. Diverticulosis

Gold standard investigation for chronic bleeding per rectum is colonoscopy aided with CECT, so option d) is correct

CEA - tumor marker for colon cancer

  • Carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (CA 19-9) is a glycoprotein synthesized by pancreatic cancer cells - tumor marker for pancreatic cancer

questions.text: There was a fracture of shaft of the femur. The patient was initially stable but gradually developed a rash over the axilla and chest in the next 12 hours, his vitals are now unstable. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Above history of long bone fracture with development of petechial rash over axilla and chest wall is suggestive of fat embolism

GURD AND WILSON CRITERIA FOR FAT EMBOLISM

Option b, c, d does not match with the history and presentation so they are wrong options

questions.text: A surgeon reduced the hernia without dissection of its content. What is it called as?
questions.solution:
Reduction en-masse

  • Migration of a hernial sac along with its entrapped content into the properitoneal space. Usually due to forceful reduction of a hernia. Although non-visible, the pathologic process is on-going Patient does not improve and continues to deteriorate after reduction
  • TAXIS test - medial rotation of though with flexion of hip, slowly compress the hernia, where surgeon tries to reduce the irreducible hernia → dangerous complication of obstruction → gangrene or perforation of bowel. So taxis test is not advised now

Option b) maydl's hernia: 2 adjacent loops of small intestine are within a hernia sac with a tight neck. The intervening portion of bowel within the abdomen is deprived of blood supply and eventually becomes necrotic

Option c) incarceration: its an irreducible hernia consisting food particles

Option d) sliding hernia: hernia sac with posterior relation of large bowel. In this condition, posterior contents should not be dissected. Instead it should be just pushed back.

Reference: https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Our-case-illustration-It-is-a-recurrent-left-inguinal-hernia-of-Zollinger-classification_fig5_262072650

questions.text:
Which of the following is not seen in about claudication pain?
1. Rest Pain at night
2. Pain starts on taking the first step
3. Most common cause of atheroma
4. Clinical presentation is not related the affected side
questions.solution:
Intermittent claudication

Intermittent claudication occurs as a result of anaerobic muscle metabolism and is classically described as debilitating cramp-like pain felt in the muscles that is:

  • brought on by walking;
  • not present on taking the first step (unlike osteoarthritis);
  • relieved by rest in both the standing and sitting positions, usually within 5 minutes (unlike nerve compression from a lumbar intervertebral disc prolapse or osteoarthritis of the spine or spinal stenosis, which are typically relieved only when resting in the sitting position for longer than 5 minutes).

Rest pain

  • As disease progression occurs the claudication distance decreases and perfusion to the leg may be so severely compromised that anaerobic respiration occurs even at rest (throughout day but worse at night), typically affecting the foot and/or calf.
  • The pain is exacerbated by lying down or elevation of the foot because of the loss of gravitational effects on the perfusion pressure in the foot. The patient characteristically describes pain that is worse at night and may be lessened by hanging the foot out of bed or by sleeping in a chair (effects of gravity restored).

KEYTAKEAWAYS:

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions has smoking as a risk factor?
1. Fibroadenoma
2. Mondor disease
3. Carcinoma
4. Duct ectasia
questions.solution:
• Smoking doesn't not increase risk of Fibroadenoma.
  • Duct ectasia, Mondor's disease, Breast carcinoma are associated with smoking.

questions.solution:
Relations of 3rd part of duodenum:

Gall bladder is related to 1st part of duodenum

questions.text: Which of the following is not a complication of parent real nutrition?
questions.solution:
• Option a) Central Line related complication: most common is arterial puncture (subclavian artery), pneumothorax, chylothorax, sepsis
  • Option c) Metabolic bone disease and vitamin defciencies. Osteoporosis or osteomalacia are both known complications of long-term parenteral nutrition, leading to fractures or kidney stones.
  • Option b) Refeeding syndrome. One of the most signifcant metabolic complications of both parenteral and enteral feeding is refeeding syndrome. This occurs in the frst days after feeding is commenced in patients who have been severely malnourished, there is decreased phosphate (hypophosphatemia) is a characteristic feature of referring syndrome)
  • Option d) Aspiration is a complication of enteral nutrition

KEYTAKEAWAYS:

questions.text: Most common cause of adrenal incidentaloma is:
questions.solution: An asymptomatic adrenal mass detected on imaging not performed for suspected adrenal disease is termed an incidentaloma. The aetiology includes benign and malignant tumours of the cortex and medulla or of extra-adrenal origin. These tumours can be either non-functioning (silent) or functioning (secreting excess hormones

questions.text: A patient presents with dysuria and flank pain which are diagnose as renal calculi. This has been a recurrent problem with the patient with the patient. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with it?
questions.solution:
• Primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT) is dominated by those with osteitis fbrosa cystica. Brown tumours of the long bones and associated subperiosteal bone reabsorption, distal tapering of the clavicles and the classical 'salt and pepper' erosions of the skull were typical findings.
  • Over 80% of patients had associated renal stones, significant neuromuscular dysfunction, and muscle weakness. This led to the traditional mnemonic that patients with PHPT presented with 'bones, stones, abdominal groans, and psychiatric overtones'

questions.text: An MRCP image is shown below. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above given image is a MRCP (magnetic resonance cholangio pancreatico graphy) - it's a T2 weighted MRI with bile itself acting as contrast

MRCP is the investigation of choice for CBD stones

MRCP with multiple filling defect (meniscus sign) at distal CBD.

Definitive treatment for distal CBD stones: ERCP sphincterotomy

(in ERCP, we can see endoscope)

questions.text: Massive blood transfusion complications are all except
questions.solution:
Massive transfusion in adult: > 10 units of blood transfused with in 24hrs

Complications from massive transfusion Complications from massive transfusion include:

C - Coagulopathy

A - Acidosis/Alkalosis

T - hypoThermia

C - hypoCalcaemia (due to Citrate)

H - Hyperkalaemia, Hypokalaemia

Both hyperkalemia and hypokalemia can be seen with massive blood transfusions but hyperkalemia is more common with massive blood transfusions compared to hypokalemia due to lysis of RBCs.

  • Why?
    • Potassium in stored blood increases due to decrease in ATP production and leakage of potassium. The initial high levels of potassium in stored blood predispose to post-transfusion hyperkalemia.

questions.text: Which one is right match in the following appendix positions in the image.
questions.solution: • The position of the base of the appendix is constant, being found at the confluence of the three taeniae coli of the caecum, which fuse to form the outer longitudinal muscle coat of the appendix. At operation, use can be made of this to find an elusive appendix, as gentle traction on the taenia coli, particularly the anterior taenia, will lead the operator to the base of the appendix.

choices.text: USG can differentiate solid and cystic lesion
USG not helpful in young females with dense breasts

questions.text: False about USG and mammography is
questions.solution:
• Ultrasonography is the primary imaging modality in young women with dense breast tissue in whom mammograms are difficult to interpret.
  • Ultrasonography can distinguish cystic from solid lesions. Simple cysts do not require further work-up and follow-up can be avoided.
  • Therapeutic aspiration may be performed for cysts causing pain.
  • A well-circumscribed, mobile, solid mass in a young woman is suggestive of a fibroadenoma and has an extremely low likelihood of malignancy.
  • Solid masses with an irregular shape and ill-defined margins (indistinct, angular or spiculated) are suspicious for malignancy and require biopsy.
  • Ultrasonography of the axilla is performed when cancer is diagnosed, with guided percutaneous biopsy of any suspicious lymph glands.
  • Mammography is done in 2 planes-cranio caudal and mediolateral oblique view, which can help in detecting deeper lesions

questions.text: Identify the lesion shown in the image
questions.solution:
• Ranula is a mucous extravasation cyst of sublingual salivary gland
  • They appear as a characteristic bluish swelling in the anterior floor of the mouth and resemble the belly or air sac of a frog.
  • They can remain localised or insinuate through the mylohyoid muscle to present as a submental swelling called a 'plunging ranula'.
  • Retention cyst - These result from obstruction of the duct by periductal scars, sialolithiasis (salivary gland stone formation) or pressure from surrounding tissue. These cysts are mainly found in the ductal system of a minor salivary gland
  • Dermoid cysts are benign congenital choristomas of the orbit that originate from fetal bone suture lines during development, most commonly the frontozygomatic suture, although they may also occur more medially.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male was brought to the casualty after a road traffic accident with pelvic fracture in hypovolemic shock. What is the earliest treatment for control of haemorrhage?
questions.solution:
• Pelvic injuries can produce a real threat to the circulation, and management is geared towards controlling this threat. Initial management requires the use of a compression binder or a sheet, applied around the true pelvis at the level of the greater trochanters ('reduce the pelvic volume'), a potentially life-saving procedure that has to be done in the emergency department.
  • Eighty-five per cent of bleeding originating from the pelvis is of venous origin and can be controlled by non-operative means, including compression either by binding or external fixator or by extraperitoneal pelvic packing (i.e. packing the loose space between the bony wall of the pelvis and the peritoneum) to compress the pelvic veins.
  • If other sources of bleeding have been ruled out, the extraperitoneal pelvic packing is done without entering the peritoneal cavity. This may be combined with external fixation.
  • If the bleeding is of arterial origin, interventional angio embolisation is the next choice for bleeding control. The techniques for bleeding control (compression, packing, fixation and angioembolization) do not exclude each other but rather may complement each other.
  • Persistent bleeding after packing may require angioembolization and vice versa. Severe pelvic injuries require a multidisciplinary team approach.
  • If the source of the bleeding is in doubt or FAST/CT results are positive, showing a significant amount of blood in the peritoneal cavity, concurrent intra-abdominal injury cannot be excluded and it is wise to perform an exploratory laparotomy to treat or rule out intra-abdominal bleeding.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about thymoma?
questions.solution:
This is the most common mediastinal tumour, accounting for 25% of the total, and is derived from the thymus gland the thymus is located in the upper anterior portion of the mediastinum.

  • Thymomas vary in behaviour from benign to aggressively invasive, as reflected in the Masaoka classification system used to stage thymomas and more recently the TNM classification.
  • Symptoms at presentation are related to local mass effects causing chest pain, dyspnea, hemoptysis, cough, and superior vena cava syndrome or systemic syndromes caused by immunologic mechanisms. (not dysphagia)
  • The only reliable indicator of malignancy is capsular invasion. Diagnosis and treatment are best achieved by complete thymectomy, which for large tumours (>5 cm) Computed tomography scan showing a thymoma presenting as a mediastinal mass. or if tumour invasion is suspected a median sternotomy is performed.
  • If the thymoma is small or when the patient has myasthenia gravis and the thymus is being excised as a treatment, various less invasive approaches can be considered, including a VATS approach or a transcervical approach with or without an additional VATS procedure.
  • Neurogenic tumors are most common posterior mediastinal tumors.

questions.text: Identify the surgical instrument shown in the image
questions.solution: • Mixter Haemostatic Forceps are versatile surgery instruments used to clamp the blood vessels and prevent blood loss.
